results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures the visit of Australian champion golfer Peter Thomson to the Wangaratta Golf Club in 1956. As shown by the poster in the film, Thomson teaches a golf clinic to an avid crowd. At the time, Thomson had won the British Open twice, and would go on to win it a total of five times - he was the first Australian golfer to win the championship and the only man to have won it in three consecutive years in the twentieth century (1954, 1955 and 1956).

The film shows off the lovely surrounds of the Golf Club set against the backdrop of the town itself and in particular, the backyards of houses. The golfers are particularly smartly dressed in clothes suitable for striding around the course with their golf bags and trolleys, the women in pleated or full mid calf skirts and the men tucking ties into shirts and full 1950s style trousers.

In this film, we can feel the atmosphere of Wangaratta in the post war period - a growing, prosperous community with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook thanks to an influx of migrants to the area.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Golf Club ‘
00:00:25:00 four golfers appraoching a green wearing stylish golfing clothes of the era
00:01:09:00 golfers shaking hands
00:01:38:00 a particularly nice pink hat on a golfer and an example of the 1950s style golf cart
00:02:09:00 more examples of golfing fashion including sun visors
00:03:19:00 a woman carries her cardigan and bag on her golf cart
00:04:02:00 a closer look at a golf bag in a cart
00:04:27:00 post golf drinks at the clubhouse
00:04:51:00 advertising leaflet for ‘Exhibition Golf and Clinic by Peter Thomson (Dual British Open Champion)’, described as the ‘Greatest Golf Day in History’ followed by scenes of the golf clinic in action
00:04:53:00 a woman with a camera taking shots of Thomson as he conducts the golf clinic
00:05:55:00 views of the large crowd at the golf clinic
00:06:30:00 close-up of Thomson’s golfclubs engraved with his name in protective covers with pom poms
00:06:39:00 a man tees off with a cigarette in his mouth
00:07:00:00 the crowd of onlookers surge forward following a player whlist holding up the boundary rope
00:07:44:00 everyone focused on the player as he lines up a shot
00:08:25:00 Thomson giving lessons on how to grip the golf club in the golf clinic
00:09:45:00 close-up of the crowd
00:11:14:00 local golfers say hello to the camera with lovely old houses behind the golf course
00:12:48:00 a golfer in a 1950s style hat likely to be a ‘Stetson’ and his tie tucked into his shirt leans casually on his golfclub before we see him toss his cigarette stub behind him
00:13:07:00 a refreshment tent set up near the golf course clubhouse with people relaxed
00:13:42:00 ladies and beers at the refreshment tent
00:13:50:00 the camera pans an attentative crowd of onlookers
00:14:47:00 the large crowd follow the play under huge lovely trees on the golf course

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.
results.title_for_label: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: Pitcha this : youth telling stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Jade Colgan, Kalimna Andy, Lionel Austin, Nicole Hucks, Rebecca Phillips, Simone Andy, Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous youth tell their own stories about who they are and where they come from. They proudly describe the places and people that inspire them and connect them to their heritage. In doing so, they provide an examination of what it is to grow up Indigenous in Australia in the 1990s, how to engage with your spirituality and identity today.
results.title_for_label: Pitcha this : youth telling stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jade Colgan, Kalimna Andy, Lionel Austin, Nicole Hucks, Rebecca Phillips, Simone Andy, Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Where she belongs...
results.creator_credit: Nicole Hucks, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nikki Butler pays tribute to her Nana, a strong, knowledgeable Aboriginal women. Despite being a part of the Stolen Generation and growing up away from her land, Nana has taught Butler so much about her heritage, culture and land. Butler hopes to be with her when Nana does finally return home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicole Hucks, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Ngi bali, hello welcome
results.creator_credit: Jade Colgan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jade Colgan may not be easily recognised as Indigenous in Melbourne but she feels connected to her homeland up the Darling River, where she spends her family holidays. Her time there has taught Colgan that life is about laughing, learning and doing the things that help you find out who you are.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jade Colgan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My Nan
results.creator_credit: Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Elsie Jones was a respected Aboriginal elder and a lovely woman, the kind of lady you never forget. She died when Teialah Mason was six but has left an indelible impression on her and has inspired in Mason pride in her heritage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Elsie Jones was a respected Aboriginal elder and a lovely woman, the kind of lady you never forget. She died when Teialah Mason was six but has left an indelible impression on her and has inspired in Mason pride in her heritage.

results.title: My island home
results.creator_credit: Lionel Austin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Lionel Austin, has lived in Melbourne all his life, his demons reside there. Where he finds his peace is Fraser Island, a natual wonderland and, ultimately, where his heart resides.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lionel Austin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: While Lionel Austin, has lived in Melbourne all his life, his demons reside there. Where he finds his peace is Fraser Island, a natual wonderland and, ultimately, where his heart resides.

results.title: My Grandfather TL
results.creator_credit: Simone Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Simone Andy’s fondly recalls her great-grandfather Thomas Lyon or, as he was known, Grandfather TL. A proud, strong Aboriginal man, Grandfather TL fought in the war and finally recieved his medals in 1996. His death in 1989 set Andy on a journey to find out more about her beloved great-grandfather and, ultimately, to find out who she is.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Simone Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Simone Andy’s fondly recalls her great-grandfather Thomas Lyon or, as he was known, Grandfather TL. His death in 1989 set Andy on a journey to find out more about her beloved great-grandfather and, ultimately, to find out who she is.
